required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Etanercept Treatment in Patients With Moderate to Severe Plaque Psoriasis Who Lost Response to Adalimumab
clinical_study.official_title: Open Label Study to Evaluate the Efficacy of Etanercept Treatment in Subjects With Moderate to Severe Plaque Psoriasis Who Have Lost a Satisfactory Response to Adalimumab

brief_summary.textblock: This study will evaluate the efficacy of etanercept in patients with plaque psoriasis who have lost a satisfactory response to adalimumab.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Business decision due to slow enrollment

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With an sPGA Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear) at Week 12
primary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). A sPGA response is defined as a sPGA value of clear (score 0) or almost clear (score 1).

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With an sPGA Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear) at Week 12 by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status
primary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). A sPGA response is defined as a sPGA value of clear (score 0) or almost clear (score 1).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With an sPGA Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear) at All Other Visits
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). A sPGA response is defined as a sPGA value of clear (score 0) or almost clear (score 1).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With an sPGA Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear) at All Other Visits by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). A sPGA response is defined as a sPGA value of clear (score 0) or almost clear (score 1).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With an sPGA Score of 0, 1 or 2 at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). The percentage of participants with a score of 0 (clear), 1 (almost clear) or 2 (mild) is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With an sPGA Score of 0, 1 or 2 by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). The percentage of participants with a score of 0 (clear), 1 (almost clear) or 2 (mild) is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Static Physician Global Assessment (sPGA) at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema).

secondary_outcome.measure: Static Physician Global Assessment (sPGA) by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 50 Response at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: A PASI 50 response is a 50% or greater improvement (reduction) from baseline in PASI score. The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 50 Response by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: A PASI 50 response is a 50% or greater improvement (reduction) from baseline in PASI score. The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 75 Response at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: A PASI 75 response is a 75% or greater improvement (reduction) from baseline in PASI score. The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 75 Response by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: A PASI 75 response is a 75% or greater improvement (reduction) from baseline in PASI score. The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 90 Response at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: A PASI 90 response is a 90% or greater improvement (reduction) from baseline in PASI score. The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 90 Response by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status at Each Visit
secondary_outcome.description: A PASI 90 response is a 90% or greater improvement (reduction) from baseline in PASI score. The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least a 1 Grade Improvement in sPGA From Baseline
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). The percentage of participants with an improvement from baseline of ≥ 1 grade is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least a 1 Grade Improvement in sPGA From Baseline by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). The percentage of participants with an improvement from baseline of ≥ 1 grade is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least a 2 Grade Improvement in sPGA From Baseline
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). The percentage of participants with an improvement from baseline of ≥ 2 grades is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least a 2 Grade Improvement in sPGA From Baseline by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). The percentage of participants with an improvement from baseline of ≥ 2 grades is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI)
secondary_outcome.description: The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis. Percent change from baseline was calculated as (Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value) / Baseline Value * 100, hence a positive value indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in PASI by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status
secondary_outcome.description: The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis. Percent change from baseline was calculated as (Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value) / Baseline Value * 100, hence a positive value indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in the Percentage of Body Surface Area (BSA) Involved With Psoriasis
secondary_outcome.description: A measurement of psoriasis involvement, given as the physician's assessment of the percentage of the participant's total body surface area (BSA) involved with psoriasis. The percent of BSA affected was estimated by assuming that the participant's palm, excluding the fingers and thumb, represented roughly 1% of the body's surface. Percent change from baseline was calculated as (Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value) / Baseline Value * 100, hence a positive value indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in the Percentage of BSA Involved With Psoriasis by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status
secondary_outcome.description: A measurement of psoriasis involvement, given as the physician's assessment of the percentage of the participant's total body surface area (BSA) involved with psoriasis. The percent of BSA affected was estimated by assuming that the participant's palm, excluding the fingers and thumb, represented roughly 1% of the body's surface. Percent change from baseline was calculated as (Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value) / Baseline Value * 100, hence a positive value indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Satisfaction With Treatment at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: Participants indicated their level of satisfaction with the medication's control of psoriasis on a scale from "very dissatisfied" to "very satisfied".

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Satisfaction With Treatment at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Participants indicated their level of satisfaction with the medication's control of psoriasis on a scale from "very dissatisfied" to "very satisfied".

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: The dermatology life quality index (DLQI) is a skin disease-specific instrument to evaluate health-related quality of life. The DLQI questionnaire asks participants to evaluate the degree that psoriasis has affected their quality of life in the last week, and includes the following parameters: symptoms and feelings, daily activities, leisure activities, work or school activities, personal relationships and treatment related feelings. Participants answered 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is from 0 (best possible score) to 30 (worst possible score). Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Work Productivity and Activity Impairment (WPAI)
secondary_outcome.description: The impact of disease severity on the participant's ability to participate in work and other activities was evaluated using the WPAI. WPAI consists of six questions to assess whether the participant was currently employed (Q1); how many hours from work were missed due to problems associated with psoriasis (Q2) or any other reason (Q3); hours actually worked (Q4); degree that psoriasis affected productivity while working (Q5); and degree that psoriasis affected regular activities (Q6) over the past 7 days. Four separate overall scores were calculated, including absenteeism (work time missed due to health), presenteeism (impairment at work due to health), work productivity loss (overall work impairment due to health), and activity impairment due to health. Each score ranges from 0 to 100 with higher scores indicating greater impairment and less productivity. Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Patient Assessment of Itch
secondary_outcome.description: The severity of the participants itch was individually assessed by the participant. Participants were asked to circle a number between 0 and 10 to describe their itch, with 0 indicating "no itch at all" and 10 indicating "worst itch imaginable." Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Patient Assessment of Pain
secondary_outcome.description: The severity of the participants pain was individually assessed by the participant. Participants were asked to circle a number between 0 and 10 to describe how much their psoriasis hurts today, with 0 indicating "does not hurt at all" and 10 indicating "worst hurt imaginable." Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Patient Assessment of Flaking
secondary_outcome.description: The severity of the participants pain was individually assessed by the participant. Participants were asked to circle a number between 0 and 10 to describe their flaking, with 0 indicating "no flaking at all" and 10 indicating "worst flaking imaginable." Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From first dose of study drug until 30 days after the last dose (up to 28 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: A treatment-related adverse event is defined as an event that is deemed by the investigator to be related to investigational product.

arm_group.description: Participants received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Moderate to severe plaque psoriasis
- Loss of satisfactory response to adalimumab
- Currently receiving or recently discontinued treatment with adalimumab
Exclusion Criteria:
- Active skin conditions that would interfere with evaluations of the effect of investigational product on psoriasis
- Serious medical conditions

reference.citation: Bagel J, Tyring S, Rice KC, Collier DH, Kricorian G, Chung J, Iles J, Stolshek BS, Kaliyaperumal A, Papp KA. Open-label study of etanercept treatment in patients with moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis who lost a satisfactory response to adalimumab. Br J Dermatol. 2017 Aug;177(2):411-418. doi: 10.1111/bjd.15381. Epub 2017 Jul 19.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This study was conducted at 48 centers in the United States (US) and Canada. Participants were enrolled from 01 February 2012 until 04 November 2014.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg
group.description: Participants received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg
group.description: Participants received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

measure.title: Age
Sex: Female, Male
Race/Ethnicity, Customized

class.title: Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Psoriasis Area Severity Index (PASI)
measure.description: The psoriasis area and severity index (PASI) score incorporates measures of erythema, desquamation, infiltration, and affected body surface area. Involvement and severity of psoriasis was scored by physicians using a scale from 0 to 72, where 0 = no psoriasis and 72 = severe disease.

measure.title: Percent of Body Surface Area (BSA) Involved in Psoriasis
Static Physician Global Assessment (sPGA) of Psoriasis
measure.description: A physician’s global assessment of the participant's psoriasis based on severity of induration, scaling, and erythema. The sPGA of psoriasis comprises a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) with increasing severity.

measure.title: Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI)
measure.description: The DLQI is a skin disease-specific instrument to evaluate health related quality of life ranging from 0 (best possible score) to 30 (worst possible score). Data were available for 63 participants.

measure.title: Patient Assessment of Flaking
measure.description: The severity of psoriasis flaking assessed by the participant on a scale between 0 and 10, with 0 indicating “no flaking at all” and 10 indicating “worst flaking imaginable.” Data were available for 63 participants.

measure.title: Patient Assessment of Itch
measure.description: The severity of a participant's itch assessed by the participant on a scale between 0 and 10, with 0 indicating “no itch at all” and 10 indicating “worst itch imaginable.” Data were available for 63 participants.

measure.title: Patient Assessment of Pain
measure.description: The severity of the participant's psoriasis pain assessed by the participant on a scale between 0 and 10, with 0 indicating “does not hurt at all” and 10 indicating “worst hurt imaginable.” Data were available for 63 participants.

measure.title: Patient Assessment of Treatment Satisfaction
measure.description: Participants indicated their level of satisfaction with the medication’s control of psoriasis on a scale from “very dissatisfied” to “very satisfied”. The response scale was adapted from the Medical Outcomes Study: Patient Satisfaction Survey.

measure.title: Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status at Screening

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With an sPGA Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear) at Week 12
outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). A sPGA response is defined as a sPGA value of clear (score 0) or almost clear (score 1).
outcome.population: The primary analysis set (all participants who received at least one dose of investigational product during the study) with at least 1 post-baseline value. Participants with missing post-baseline data were imputed using the last observation carried forward (LOCF) method.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg
group.description: Participants received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). A sPGA response is defined as a sPGA value of clear (score 0) or almost clear (score 1).
outcome.population: The primary analysis set with available data

group.title: Anti-adalimumab Antibody Positive
group.description: Participants who were anti-adalimumab antibody positive at screening received etanercept 50 mg, BIW, subcutaneously for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, QW for an additional 12 weeks.

group.title: Anti-adalimumab Antibody Negative
group.description: Participants who were anti-adalimumab antibody negative at screening received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With an sPGA Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear) at Week 12 by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 50 Response by Anti-adalimumab Antibody Status at Each Visit
measure.description: A PASI 50 response is a 50% or greater improvement (reduction) from baseline in PASI score. The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis.
measure.population: Primary analysis set participants with available data

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 75 Response at Each Visit
outcome.description: A PASI 75 response is a 75% or greater improvement (reduction) from baseline in PASI score. The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With at Least a 1 Grade Improvement in sPGA From Baseline
outcome.description: The sPGA is a 6-point scale ranging from 0 (clear) to 5 (very severe) used to measure the severity of disease (induration, scaling, and erythema). The percentage of participants with an improvement from baseline of ≥ 1 grade is reported.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used.

outcome.title: Percent Change From Baseline in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI)
outcome.description: The PASI measures the average redness (erythema), thickness (induration), and scaliness (each graded on a 0 to 4 scale) of psoriasis lesions, weighted by the area of involvement in the four main body areas (i.e., head and neck, trunk, upper extremities, and lower extremities). PASI scores can range from 0 to 72, with higher scores indicating greater severity and/or more extensive psoriasis. Percent change from baseline was calculated as (Baseline Value – Post-baseline Value) / Baseline Value * 100, hence a positive value indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used.

outcome.title: Percent Change From Baseline in the Percentage of Body Surface Area (BSA) Involved With Psoriasis
outcome.description: A measurement of psoriasis involvement, given as the physician’s assessment of the percentage of the participant’s total body surface area (BSA) involved with psoriasis. The percent of BSA affected was estimated by assuming that the participant’s palm, excluding the fingers and thumb, represented roughly 1% of the body’s surface. Percent change from baseline was calculated as (Baseline Value – Post-baseline Value) / Baseline Value * 100, hence a positive value indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used.

group.description: Participants received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

outcome.title: Patient Satisfaction With Treatment at Week 12
outcome.description: Participants indicated their level of satisfaction with the medication’s control of psoriasis on a scale from “very dissatisfied” to “very satisfied”.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) Total Score
outcome.description: The dermatology life quality index (DLQI) is a skin disease-specific instrument to evaluate health-related quality of life. The DLQI questionnaire asks participants to evaluate the degree that psoriasis has affected their quality of life in the last week, and includes the following parameters: symptoms and feelings, daily activities, leisure activities, work or school activities, personal relationships and treatment related feelings. Participants answered 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is from 0 (best possible score) to 30 (worst possible score). Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value – Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used. n indicates the number of participants included in the analysis at each time point.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg
group.description: Participants received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) Total Score
measure.description: The dermatology life quality index (DLQI) is a skin disease-specific instrument to evaluate health-related quality of life. The DLQI questionnaire asks participants to evaluate the degree that psoriasis has affected their quality of life in the last week, and includes the following parameters: symptoms and feelings, daily activities, leisure activities, work or school activities, personal relationships and treatment related feelings. Participants answered 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is from 0 (best possible score) to 30 (worst possible score). Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value – Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.
measure.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used. n indicates the number of participants included in the analysis at each time point.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Work Productivity and Activity Impairment (WPAI)
outcome.description: The impact of disease severity on the participant’s ability to participate in work and other activities was evaluated using the WPAI. WPAI consists of six questions to assess whether the participant was currently employed (Q1); how many hours from work were missed due to problems associated with psoriasis (Q2) or any other reason (Q3); hours actually worked (Q4); degree that psoriasis affected productivity while working (Q5); and degree that psoriasis affected regular activities (Q6) over the past 7 days. Four separate overall scores were calculated, including absenteeism (work time missed due to health), presenteeism (impairment at work due to health), work productivity loss (overall work impairment due to health), and activity impairment due to health. Each score ranges from 0 to 100 with higher scores indicating greater impairment and less productivity. Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value and who were employed (for the first 3 scores); LOCF imputation was used. n indicates the number of participants included in the analysis at each time point.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg
group.description: Participants received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Work Productivity and Activity Impairment (WPAI)
measure.description: The impact of disease severity on the participant’s ability to participate in work and other activities was evaluated using the WPAI. WPAI consists of six questions to assess whether the participant was currently employed (Q1); how many hours from work were missed due to problems associated with psoriasis (Q2) or any other reason (Q3); hours actually worked (Q4); degree that psoriasis affected productivity while working (Q5); and degree that psoriasis affected regular activities (Q6) over the past 7 days. Four separate overall scores were calculated, including absenteeism (work time missed due to health), presenteeism (impairment at work due to health), work productivity loss (overall work impairment due to health), and activity impairment due to health. Each score ranges from 0 to 100 with higher scores indicating greater impairment and less productivity. Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.
measure.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value and who were employed (for the first 3 scores); LOCF imputation was used. n indicates the number of participants included in the analysis at each time point.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Patient Assessment of Itch
outcome.description: The severity of the participants itch was individually assessed by the participant. Participants were asked to circle a number between 0 and 10 to describe their itch, with 0 indicating “no itch at all” and 10 indicating “worst itch imaginable.” Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used. n indicates the number of participants included in the analysis at each time point.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg
group.description: Participants received etanercept 50 mg, twice weekly (BIW), subcutaneously (SC) for 12 weeks followed by 50 mg, once weekly (QW), SC for an additional 12 weeks.

measure.description: The severity of the participants itch was individually assessed by the participant. measure.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used. n indicates the number of participants included in the analysis at each time point.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Patient Assessment of Pain
outcome.description: The severity of the participants pain was individually assessed by the participant. Participants were asked to circle a number between 0 and 10 to describe how much their psoriasis hurts today, with 0 indicating “does not hurt at all” and 10 indicating “worst hurt imaginable.” Change from baseline was calculated as Baseline Value - Post-baseline Value, hence a positive change indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Primary analysis set participants with at least 1 post-baseline value; LOCF imputation was used. n indicates the number of participants included in the analysis at each time point.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events
outcome.description: A treatment-related adverse event is defined as an event that is deemed by the investigator to be related to investigational product.
outcome.time_frame: From first dose of study drug until 30 days after the last dose (up to 28 weeks)
outcome.population: Primary analysis set

group.title: Etanercept 50mg BIW/50mg QW

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The Clinical Trial Agreement generally does not restrict an investigator's discussion of trial results after completion. The Agreement permits Amgen a limited period of time to review material discussing trial results (typically up to 45 days and possible extension). Amgen may remove confidential information, but authors have final control and approval of publication content. For multicenter studies, the investigator agrees not to publish any results before the first multi-center publication.
